Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Waterborne Elizabethkingia disinfection studies in response to ongoing U.S. outbreak

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1700604
Mayer

There is an ongoing outbreak in the U.S caused by Elizabethkingia bacteria. Elizabethkingia is a ubiquitous group of bacteria whose presence in soil and water ordinarily pose little risk to human health. However, the current outbreak includes 63 confirmed cases, and has been associated with 18 confirmed fatalities since November 2015. This opportunistic human pathogen is particularly alarming because it tends to exhibit a high degree of antibiotic resistance and mortality. Given the emergence of this pathogen and the ongoing outbreak, it is important to develop a better understanding of how to effectively control these bacteria in drinking water.

This RAPID research project will provide the first direct assessment of inactivation of waterborne Elizabethkingia bacteria using chlorination, chloramination, ozonation, and ultraviolet (UV) irradiation. Specific objectives of the proposed work include the following. Characterize the disinfection response of: 1) planktonic cells, 2) attached cells, and 3) develop a deeper understanding of the relationship between disinfection efficacy and Elizabethkingia composition. Laboratory experiments will be used to establish concentration (or UV intensity) x time relationships (referred to as CT relationships). This disinfectant response data is currently unknown, and is urgently needed to develop effective disinfection strategies to curtail the current outbreak and avoid future public health disasters. Additionally, this project will probe the relationship between the bacteria's composition (nucleic and amino acids) and susceptibility to different modes of disinfection. The proposed research will substantially contribute to advancing broader societal outcomes including improved understanding of drinking water disinfection strategies to better protect human health, which has immediate implications for curtailing the ongoing outbreak caused by Elizabethkingia bacteria and for preventing future outbreaks. Findings from this project will also be integrated into course modules/discussions in the PIs regular teaching rotation, a summer experience for high school students, and at the Emerging Contaminants Short Course offered annually at Marquette University for academics and professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Elizabethkingia bacteria tend to exhibit a high degree of antibiotic resistance and mortality, and are widely acknowledged to be opportunistic nosocomial human pathogens. In 2015-2016, southeastern Wisconsin experienced an outbreak caused by Elizabethkingia anophelis, leading to 66 confirmed cases (including 2 patients from Illinois and 1 from Michigan), 18 of which were fatal. This outbreak was particularly alarming due to the large number of cases and deaths ? it was the largest documented Elizabethkingia outbreak in history. The majority of the patients were over 65 years of age and had at least one serious underlying illness in their health history.

While the genetic signature of the bacterial infections in the Wisconsin outbreak (caused by a single strain of a novel phylogenetic E. anophelis sublineage) pointed to a single source, analysis of samples from the patients, tap water, environments in common facilities and patient homes, and consumer products were all negative. Tap water was initially suspected, as previous outbreaks of Elizabethkingia meningoseptica have been linked to hospital water sources; however, water samples tested negative for the presence of the bacteria. Notwithstanding the negative test results in tap water for the Wisconsin outbreak, prior outbreaks provide evidence of Elizabethkingia colonizing sinks, piping, and aerators. Several studies of these outbreaks suggest that Elizabethkingia exhibits resistance to chlorine disinfection. However, there have been no known studies designed to assess the susceptibility of waterborne Elizabethkingia to common disinfection treatment processes.

Accordingly, the main objective of this project was to evaluate the disinfection response of Elizabethkingia bacteria to common water disinfectants (free chlorine, chloramines, ozone, and UV [ultraviolet; light emitting diodes emitting at peaks of 255, 265, and 285 nm were used here]). The central hypothesis of this work was that Elizabethkingia would demonstrate resistance to chlorine-based disinfectants (increased resistance relative to bacteria in general, i.e., E. coli), whereas ozone and UV were expected to provide greater disinfection efficacy. This hypothesis was tested through three related, but independent, specific objectives:

1) Characterize the disinfection response of planktonic (suspended) Elizabethkingia cells.

2) Characterize the disinfection response of detached Elizabethkingia cells (cultured in attached growth mode).

3) Develop a deeper understanding of the relationship between disinfection efficacy and Elizabethkingia composition.

Comparing all disinfectants tested in this study, ozone was clearly the most effective for inactivation of Elizabethkingia meningoseptica (both planktonic and detached cells), whereas chloramine and UV265 offered the lowest disinfection efficacy. Overall, UV255 seemed to be more effective than free chlorine, although differences were observed comparing the response of planktonic cells relative to detached cells. For planktonic cells, the Ct (Concentration * time, mg-min/L) or It (Intensity * time, mJ/cm2) needed to achieve 2-logs Elizabethkingia inactivation was 0.14, 4.68, 4.94, 14.17, 21.02, and 36.04 using ozone, UV285, UV255, free chlorine (at pH 7, temperature 25oC, 4 mg/L Cl2), chloramine, and UV265, respectively.

In comparison to other vegetative bacteria cells, our results demonstrated that Elizabethkingia is generally more resistant to chlorine disinfection. Based on literature, the free chlorine Ct requirement for Elizabethkingia was more similar to Giardia than other non-spore forming bacteria. These results support previous suggestions that Elizabethkingia cells may exhibit elevated chlorine resistance. However, Elizabethkingia was less resistant to chloramines in comparison to the other broad classes of microorganisms. Relative to other bacteria, Elizabethkingia was slightly more resistant to UV irradiation at a wavelength of 254-255 nm, although its profile was similar to other bacteria, Cryptosporidium, and Giardia. In comparison to several other non-spore forming waterborne bacteria, the UV inactivation profile of Elizabethkingia was most similar to Legionella pneumophila.

Analysis of 28 different published bacterial sequences (including 19 E. anophelis, 4 E. meningoseptica, and 5 other bacteria strains [E. coli, L. pneumophila, Vibrio cholerae, and Salmonella], all from the NCBI database) showed high homogeneity in nucleotide and amino acid composition amongst the Elizabethkingia strains. However, the average GC (guanine/cytosine) content of Elizabethkingia cells was lower compared to the other bacteria. There were also relative differences amongst many of the amino acids, yet the theoretical division of nucleotide versus amino acid reactions (damage) was nearly identical for all species, with 98% of oxidative damage in the amino acids, while 98% of photolytic damage was in the nucleotides. The influence of such compositional differences and other factors such as structural organization, cellular response mechanisms, etc. is not yet established, but would considerably strengthen understanding of Elizabethkingia inactivation mechanisms and disinfection response profiles.

These results are significant for water treatment applications, particularly in relation to waterborne outbreaks, e.g., in hospital settings. They indicate that more advanced disinfection is needed to reduce the risks of waterborne Elizabethkingia infection.
